answers.author: Evelina Moulder
answers.text:
Hi Monica,  
The results of both ICMA's 2012 and 2013 Police and Fire Personnel and Expenditures Surveys show that close to 75% of municipalities report that their police officers work a 40-hour week. In 2013, 32% report an 8-hour shift, and  56% report a 10/12 hour shift.  I hope this is useful.

answers.author: Leonard Matarese
answers.text:
Before considering any schedule, the workload must be studied. One needs to know the workload demand first and then implement a schedule that deploys officers when they are needed. Essentially deployment should track workload with about a 60% average  committed rate and a 40% non-committed ratio. The schedule must be designed to allow this type of coverage.  
The Police Foundation study found that there were no differences in physical effects on officers between 8, 10 and 12 hour shifts and no impact on accidents , etc. It did find that officers prefer a 10 hour shift which is not surprising since it can result in more days off. 
For more information on workload vs. deployment, see the white paper on the ICMA Center for Public Safety Management website.

answers.author: Paul Poczobut
answers.text:
I'm interested in the results of your request.  I have officers doing 11.5 hour shifts and I believe the stress and fatigue of these type shifts can make it unsafe for not just the officer but the public as well.  But then I may be wrong.

author: Monica Jones
text:
I'm interested in learning what analysis other jurisdictions have conducted on the subject of police shift lengths, and the decisions that were made as a result of this analysis. Specifically, 8 hour, 10 hour, or 12 hour shifts. 
Also, have any jurisdictions recently made a change from one length to another, and if so, what has that experience been like?
title: Police Schedules
